recipes.title: Heze & Aza Make Fish & Chips!
recipes.intro: The twins are at the seaside! Let’s make the UK’s favourite meal together!
recipes.introFact: Fish and chips is the UK’s most famous takeaway!
recipes.completionMessage: Crispy fish and golden chips — dinner is served!
recipes.completionFact: The first fish and chip shop opened in Britain in the 1860s.

steps.story: Aza peels the potatoes — tap to chop them into chips!
steps.fact: British chips are thick and chunky, not thin like French fries!

steps.story: Heze mixes the batter — drag the flour into the bowl!
steps.fact: The batter is made bubbly with fizzy water for extra crunch.

steps.story: Dip the fish in the batter — tap to coat it!
steps.fact: Cod and haddock are the most popular fish for this dish.

steps.story: Stir the chips in the fryer so they turn golden!
steps.fact: Golden chips should be crispy outside and fluffy inside!

steps.story: Hold to let everything cook to a perfect golden brown!
steps.fact: British people love to add salt, vinegar, and mushy peas on the side.

recipes.title: Aza Bakes Scones!
recipes.intro: It’s afternoon tea time! Aza is baking scones with clotted cream and jam.
recipes.introFact: Afternoon tea was invented in the 1840s by a duchess who got hungry between meals!
recipes.completionMessage: Warm, fluffy scones with cream and jam — time for tea!
recipes.completionFact: People in Devon put cream first, but people in Cornwall put jam first!

steps.story: Tap to sift the flour into the bowl!
steps.fact: Sifting flour adds air and makes scones extra fluffy.

steps.story: Drag the butter into the flour and rub it with your fingers!
steps.fact: Cold butter makes the best scones — it creates flaky layers!

steps.story: Stir the dough gently — don’t mix too much!
steps.fact: Over-stirring makes scones tough — gentle hands make them light!

steps.story: Hold to bake the scones in the oven until golden!
steps.fact: Scones have been baked in Britain for hundreds of years!

recipes.title: Heze Makes a Full Breakfast!
recipes.intro: Good morning! Heze is making a proper Full English breakfast for the whole family!
recipes.introFact: A Full English is also called a “fry-up” because almost everything is fried!
recipes.completionMessage: A huge, sizzling breakfast plate — the best way to start the day!
recipes.completionFact: Every region in the UK has its own version — Scottish, Welsh, and Irish too!

steps.story: Tap to crack the eggs into the pan!
steps.fact: Fried eggs with runny yolks are the classic British style!

steps.story: Drag the bacon and sausages into the pan!
steps.fact: Back bacon is the most popular type of bacon in the UK.

steps.story: Stir the baked beans in their pot!
steps.fact: British people eat over 2 million cans of baked beans every day!

steps.story: Hold to toast the bread until it’s golden and crunchy!
steps.fact: Toast soldiers — thin strips of toast — are perfect for dipping into eggs!

recipes.title: The Twins Make Shepherd’s Pie!
recipes.intro: It’s a cosy evening! Heze and Aza are making a warm shepherd’s pie together.
recipes.introFact: Shepherd’s pie uses lamb — if you use beef, it’s called cottage pie!
recipes.completionMessage: Golden, bubbly shepherd’s pie is ready — dig in!
recipes.completionFact: Shepherd’s pie was invented to use up leftover Sunday roast meat!

steps.story: Tap to chop the carrots, onions, and celery!
steps.fact: These three vegetables together are called a “mirepoix” — the flavour base!

steps.story: Drag the lamb into the pan to brown it!
steps.fact: Browning the meat first gives the pie a rich, deep flavour.

steps.story: Stir the filling with gravy until it’s thick and yummy!
steps.fact: Gravy is one of the most important parts of British cooking!

steps.story: Heze mashes the potatoes — tap to mash them smooth!
steps.fact: Adding butter and milk makes mashed potatoes extra creamy.

steps.story: Hold to bake the pie until the top is crispy and golden!
steps.fact: The mashed potato top gets crispy and golden brown in the oven!

recipes.title: Aza’s Trifle Tower!
recipes.intro: Party time! Aza is building the tallest, yummiest trifle for a celebration!
recipes.introFact: Trifle has been a British dessert for over 400 years!
recipes.completionMessage: A beautiful layered trifle — the most colourful dessert!
recipes.completionFact: The word “trifle” means something small and fun!

steps.story: Tap to break the sponge cake into pieces for the bottom layer!
steps.fact: Sponge cake soaks up the fruit juice and becomes extra yummy!

steps.story: Drag the fresh fruit on top of the sponge!
steps.fact: Strawberries, raspberries, and blueberries are the most popular trifle fruits.

steps.story: Stir the custard until it’s smooth and pour it over the fruit!
steps.fact: Custard is made from eggs, milk, and sugar — a very old British recipe!

steps.story: Drag the whipped cream on top — make it thick and fluffy!
steps.fact: Whipped cream on top makes trifle look like a cloud!

steps.story: Tap to add sprinkles and decorations on top!
steps.fact: Every family layers and decorates their trifle a little differently!

recipes.title: Heze’s Cosy Crumpets!
recipes.intro: It’s raining outside! Heze is making warm, buttery crumpets for a cosy afternoon.
recipes.introFact: Crumpets have been eaten in Britain since the 1600s!
recipes.completionMessage: Warm crumpets dripping with butter and honey — perfect for a rainy day!
recipes.completionFact: British people eat over 80 million crumpets every year!

steps.story: Tap to mix the batter — flour, yeast, and warm milk!
steps.fact: Yeast makes tiny bubbles that create the famous crumpet holes!

steps.story: Stir the batter in circles until it’s smooth!
steps.fact: The batter needs to rest so the bubbles grow bigger.

steps.story: Hold to cook the crumpets on the griddle until golden!
steps.fact: The little holes in crumpets soak up melted butter perfectly!

steps.story: Drag the butter and honey onto the warm crumpet!
steps.fact: Some people like Marmite on crumpets — you love it or you hate it!

recipes.title: The Twins Make Bangers & Mash!
recipes.intro: It’s a chilly evening! Heze and Aza are making the cosiest dinner — bangers and mash with lots of gravy!
recipes.introFact: Sausages are called “bangers” because during the war they had so much water in them they would pop and bang in the pan!
recipes.completionMessage: Sizzling sausages, creamy mash, and golden gravy — yum!
recipes.completionFact: Bangers and mash has been one of Britain’s favourite comfort foods for over 100 years!

steps.story: Heze puts the sausages in the pan — tap to turn them so they cook evenly!
steps.fact: Cumberland sausages are long and curly — they come from the Lake District!

steps.story: Aza peels the potatoes — tap to chop them into pieces!
steps.fact: Smaller potato pieces cook faster and mash more easily!

steps.story: Drag the butter and milk into the pot to make the mash creamy!
steps.fact: The secret to perfect mash is lots of butter and warm milk!

steps.story: Stir the onion gravy until it’s thick and bubbly!
steps.fact: Onion gravy is the most popular topping — some families add a splash of Worcestershire sauce!

steps.story: Hold to let the sausages finish cooking until they’re golden brown!
steps.fact: British people eat over 175,000 tonnes of sausages every year!

recipes.title: Aza’s Puffy Yorkshire Puddings!
recipes.intro: It’s Sunday roast day! Aza is making big, puffy Yorkshire puddings for the whole family!
recipes.introFact: Yorkshire pudding was first made in the north of England over 300 years ago!
recipes.completionMessage: Perfectly puffy golden Yorkshire puddings — ready for the roast!
recipes.completionFact: Yorkshire puddings puff up because the hot oil makes the batter rise really fast in the oven!

steps.story: Tap to crack the eggs into the bowl!
steps.fact: Eggs help Yorkshire puddings puff up high and golden!

steps.story: Drag the flour and milk into the bowl with the eggs!
steps.fact: The batter should be thin and runny — like single cream!

steps.story: Stir the batter until it’s completely smooth with no lumps!
steps.fact: Letting the batter rest for 30 minutes makes even puffier puddings!

steps.story: Hold to bake in a very hot oven until they puff up tall and golden!
steps.fact: Never open the oven door while they bake — they’ll deflate!

recipes.title: Heze’s Cornish Pasty Adventure!
recipes.intro: Heze is learning to make a real Cornish pasty — the famous handheld pie from Cornwall!
recipes.introFact: Cornish pasties were invented for tin miners who needed a meal they could hold with dirty hands!
recipes.completionMessage: A golden, crimped Cornish pasty — packed with delicious filling!
recipes.completionFact: The thick crimped edge was a handle — miners threw it away because their hands had tin dust on them!

steps.story: Tap to chop the beef, potato, and onion into small pieces!
steps.fact: A real Cornish pasty only has beef, potato, swede, and onion inside — nothing else!

steps.story: Drag the filling onto the pastry circle!
steps.fact: Everything goes in raw — the filling cooks inside the pastry in the oven!

steps.story: Tap to crimp the edges and seal the pasty shut!
steps.fact: Crimping is the special folding pattern along the edge — every baker has their own style!

steps.story: Hold to bake the pasty until the crust is golden and flaky!
steps.fact: A proper Cornish pasty must be made in Cornwall to use the protected name!

recipes.title: The Twins Bake Sticky Toffee Pudding!
recipes.intro: Time for dessert! Heze and Aza are baking the yummiest sticky toffee pudding with warm toffee sauce!
recipes.introFact: Sticky toffee pudding was invented in the Lake District — a beautiful area in the north of England!
recipes.completionMessage: Warm, gooey sticky toffee pudding dripping with toffee sauce — the best dessert ever!
recipes.completionFact: The secret ingredient is chopped dates — they make the sponge super moist and sweet!

steps.story: Tap to chop the dates into tiny pieces!
steps.fact: Dates are a sweet fruit that grows on palm trees in hot countries!

steps.story: Drag the flour, butter, and eggs into the mixing bowl!
steps.fact: The sponge cake in sticky toffee pudding is extra soft because of the dates!

steps.story: Stir the toffee sauce — butter, sugar, and cream — until it’s thick and glossy!
steps.fact: Toffee sauce is made by heating butter and sugar together until it bubbles and turns golden!

steps.story: Hold to bake the pudding until it’s risen and springy!
steps.fact: Sticky toffee pudding is one of the most popular desserts in British pubs!

steps.story: Tap to pour the warm toffee sauce all over the top!
steps.fact: Many people serve it with vanilla ice cream or custard on the side!
